content.body: CLDR performs some fallbacks that aren't allowed by naive subtag stripping in `"best fit"`, like en-GB to en-001 or hi-Latn to en-IN
content.formatted_body: CLDR performs some fallbacks that aren't allowed by naive subtag stripping in "best fit", like en-GB to en-001 or hi-Latn to en-IN

content.body: However, I don't think this behavior is currently observable because ICU, and therefore browsers, treat anything with a nonstandard fallback to be in the availableLocales list
The spec reads as if it is based on the UTS 35 skeleton resolution algorithm, which is the same algorithm used in ICU

For both this and `localeMatcher: "lookup"`, it's not clear to me what the motivation was to write what are essentially reference algorithms in the spec when most everyone will be using the alternative implementation-defined routines anyway
content.formatted_body: For both this and localeMatcher: "lookup", it's not clear to me what the motivation was to write what are essentially reference algorithms in the spec when most everyone will be using the alternative implementation-defined routines anyway

content.body: and since these are data-driven algorithms. People can't rely on the behavior of either `localeMatcher: "lookup"` or `BasicFormatMatcher` because they are subject to change when data changes.
content.formatted_body: and since these are data-driven algorithms. People can't rely on the behavior of either localeMatcher: "lookup" or BasicFormatMatcher because they are subject to change when data changes.
